SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. TITLE OF QUESTIONNAIRE TO THE PERSON COMPLETING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences, but there may be others which are applicable.

In preparing for your answers, you should try to recall all the facts that you can about your pioneer experiences. You may find it helpful to list them in order of their occurrence, or to make a list of things you remember. If you have any photographs or other personal memorabilia, you may wish to include them with your answers.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pictorial History," has been completed. If you have already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Canadian Pioneer Society questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life," has been completed. If you have already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer settlement and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of the Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How often did you earn money?

My father died two years after moving to New Hampshire.

April 4, 1948, Butteville K-14. The house fire burning. And I had to move quickly and break away from the fire and the smoke. I worked as a Signal Boy for two years during World War II. I left work three months earlier than usual and the very day I was going to make the trip to the field. And went to Pierre after the trip to the field.

One Reason why I stayed in Saskatchewan

While I could have stayed in the New England States. And perhaps build a more substantial fortune there than on the Prairies was that I was a Britisher. That year there was a rush of liberty land as I had never been as a boy on Prince Edward Island and my parents had installed this as a great project for the next three months. Another thing was that I did not want to work in Prills or Calgary if I wanted a job & call my own day. There that I wanted to go to the mills.

Day there all the clerks were there. This being a presidential election. All the ladies were there. (My Pal Nelson) brought down a lot of votes. We were voting in Music Hall and counted them. We were each of the officers in a large official hall. The ballot box was the superintendence of the city council. Each had a copy of the voting list. When the polls closed he was asked for his vote. He wanted to get away from that. And I thought I would send my vote by mail. So I got them from you down the mountain of Thomas and gave them to Canada in the best country to have a family in.
I would refer you to Frank Gurnett.

Some Reason why I stayed in Saskatchewan

While I could have stayed in the New England States and perhaps build there accumulated so much more wealth than on the Prairies now that I was a Britisher. That year there a wave of Liberty beckoned me. I had never been a boy on Prince Edward Island and my parents had instilled into me a great respect for the Land. Another thing was that I did not want to work in Mills or Factories. I wanted the freedom to build in the Country. I wanted to go out and call my own own work there that I could work on an election day. Also the way the farmers worked on an election day. There all the farmers were working hard. This being a Provincial Election. The candidates, Mr. Macdonald and Mr. Laurier (Mr. Laurier said let us go down to the Hall and vote in Ontario). It was a big affair. The Hall was filled with people. Each had a copy of the working list which they had to sign. The next ballot, he wanted to get away from that. And I found myself with my own thing to sign. They have gone down the mountain of time. And I felt that Canada is the best Country for raising a family in.
Some Reason why I Stayed in Saskatchewan

While I could have stayed in the New England States and perhaps could have accumulated as much or more wealth than on the Prairies, was that I was a Britsher, that I knew there abuses of liberty such as I had never seen as a boy on Prince Edward Island and my parents had installed into us a great respect for the Constitution. Christian thing was that I did not want to watch in Canada if wanted to go back to my open air hut on the Country if wanted to go back to my own. I also said there that the workmen in the Mills had to vote the way the bosses wished. On an election day there all the debates were closed. This being a Provincial Election. The Candidates, Macdonald, Haggard, My Pal Nelson (Mr. David) Red was drawn to the Voting in Music Hall and watched them vote. We were in this building was for travelling shows. Sitting up on the stage was the Mayor, returning officers. Great right behind early. The officers was a little officially by the Berlin Mills Co.

And the Superintendent of the Green Paper Mills Co. They had a copy of the voting list which the voter tipped up he was asked this question. He is anxious and who he wished to vote for. He meant this for you. Glad was before Austria but brought him in the face was the big Millman. If I gain tomorrow the next bullet. So wanted to get away from that. And I found liberty under my own flag. So this is a day I came down. The number of times, and I felt them coming down. To raise a family in Mr. Campbell's Canada in the best country to raise a family in. Mr. Campbell.
